pullRequest.body:
This will be used to solve Cauchy's functional equation.

From LeanCamCombi

Co-authored-by: Mantas Baksys

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

### PR summary [bc687681a9](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20304/commits/bc687681a9513b25af2d5b2a508c2064d5dd22e3)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ _root_.MonoidHom.exists_nhds_isBounded`
`+ div_mem_nhds_one_of_haar_pos_ne_top`
`+ image_op_smul_distrib`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

Please adjust the PR message
bors d+

:v: YaelDillies can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12619830842/job/35164819187)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12619830842/job/35164819305)
Could you adjust the PR description to the current statement?
Since mu does not appear in the conclusion, can't you also remove it from the assumptions (using the fact that we know that such an inner regular Haar measure exists)?
What's the mathlib statement that such a measure exists? I could not find it when I looked for it

Ha, you're right, we're only proving the existence of the regular version, not the inner regular one. Still, you can use the regular one to prove your lemma: it is `InnerRegularCompactLTTop` by general results (found by typeclass inference), which is enough to get Steinhaus theorem for sets `E` of finite measure (using `MeasurableSet.exists_lt_isCompact_of_ne_top`, same proof otherwise). 

And in the proof of the theorem you can make sure that you have a set of finite measure: start from a compact set `K` with nonempty interior (which has finite positive measure), then argue that `K` is covered by the `f ^{-1} (B (1, r))`, so one of `K \cap f ^{-1} (B (1, r))` has positive (and finite) measure and you're good to go.

It makes the proof a little bit more complicated, but the result is more satisfactory IMHO. I can implement this proof if you want, if you're not familiar enough with this part of the library.

Was pretty easy with your hints ð 

... although does your comment

> we're only proving the existence of the regular version, not the inner regular one.

mean that inner regular measures always exists on lcag groups? (Haar measures is one of the topics I never was formally taught) If so, maybe we should formalise that instead of working around it

Yes, inner regular measures always exist. But proving this is way harder than your lemma, so I'd go with the workaround for now. If you want, you can add a todo in the proof saying one can streamline it using an inner regular Haar measure.
Can you tweak the comment to the current situation?
What about this?

```suggestion
In any locally compact group `G` with an Haar measure `Î¼` that's inner regular on finite measure sets, for
```
(Same thing in the to_additivized version)
Could you formulate it for a general point instead of just `one`?

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: if `f` is a measurable group hom, then every point has a neighborhood `s` such that `f '' s` is bounded
